importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the announcement of Pakistan's first hyperspectral satellite launch, highlighting a significant advancement in the nation’s space capabilities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The event took place in 2025, within the context of Pakistan’s broader push to expand its space programme and technological self-reliance.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, marking a major milestone in its space programme.
The satellite was launched from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, by Pakistan’s space agency SUPARCO.
Hyperspectral technology enables detection of subtle chemical and material changes on Earth’s surface, useful for agriculture, environmental monitoring, and disaster management.
The satellite is expected to enhance national capacities in precision agriculture, urban planning, and geohazard risk identification.
The launch supports development goals like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) by improving infrastructure planning and natural resource management.
Pakistan’s space programme has expanded rapidly, with three satellites launched this year: H1, EO-1, and KS-1, of which EO-1 and KS-1 are already fully operational.
It may take approximately two months to calibrate H1’s systems before full operational status is achieved.
The mission underscores Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China in peaceful space exploration and technological cooperation.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country in South Asia that launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, as part of a national space programme.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pakistan is the central actor in the article, demonstrating a breakthrough in its space capabilities and technological advancement.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s national space agency responsible for the launch and management of the H1 satellite.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SUPARCO is the primary entity executing the mission, signaling the institutional development and capability of Pakistan’s space sector.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s first hyperspectral satellite, launched into orbit on October 19, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite represents a technological leap in Earth observation, enabling detailed environmental and agricultural monitoring.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A space launch facility in China’s northwestern region where the H1 satellite was launched.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The launch site highlights international collaboration, with Pakistan relying on China’s infrastructure for access to space.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country that hosted the launch of Pakistan’s H1 satellite and with which Pakistan maintains a strategic space partnership.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China is central to the strategic cooperation framework, providing launch services and reinforcing the bilateral space relationship.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure project linking China’s Xinjiang province with Pakistan’s Gwadar Port.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite’s data is expected to support CPEC by enabling better environmental and urban planning for infrastructure development.

namedEntities.name: Hyperspectral satellite technology
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A type of satellite imaging technology that detects subtle material and chemical changes on Earth’s surface.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The use of this technology enables precise monitoring of crops, water, and natural disasters, supporting national development goals.

namedEntities.name: Precision agriculture
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A farming method that uses data-driven techniques to optimize crop yields and resource use.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite is expected to revolutionize agriculture through improved crop quality and resource management.

namedEntities.name: Environmental monitoring
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The process of tracking environmental conditions such as pollution, deforestation, or climate change.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite supports real-time environmental observation, contributing to sustainability and climate resilience.

namedEntities.name: Urban planning
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The design and management of cities and infrastructure.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite data will assist in more efficient and sustainable urban development in Pakistan.

namedEntities.name: Disaster management
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The preparedness and response to natural disasters such as floods or earthquakes.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The ability to detect geohazards enables early warnings and better response planning in high-risk areas.

namedEntities.name: EO-1 and KS-1 satellites
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Two other satellites launched by Pakistan in 2025 that are already fully operational in orbit.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They demonstrate Pakistan’s growing capacity in space technology and provide context for the significance of H1’s launch.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, through its national space agency SUPARCO. The H1 satellite, equipped with hyperspectral imaging technology, is expected to revolutionize precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management by detecting subtle chemical and material changes on Earth’s surface. This milestone reflects Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China and supports national development goals, including those of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). While H1 will require about two months of calibration before full operational status, it marks a pivotal advancement in Pakistan’s space programme, which has expanded with three satellite launches in 2025, including already-operational EO-1 and KS-1.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
